7.78.text: that if you cut a tree down you can see the rings in it and

11.27.text: that those rings tell you how many years the tree grew for

14.32.text: what is less widely known is that the pattern

18.18.text: of those rings is a tool that we can use to both identify

22.00.text: where and when the tree grew

25.43.text: each individual tree has its own pattern

28.94.text: that is reflecting things that happened to that individual tree in its lifetime

36.71.text: have similar patterns in such a way that we can use them as a tool

40.12.text: to both locate, in an approximate sense, where trees come from

44.16.text: and very precisely when they were growing

47.80.text: When we date a board we date the last ring that is present in the board and we

53.88.text: make certain estimates or make certain assumptions about the way the trees are

57.91.text: converted into boards and how much loss there is along the way

61.38.text: in order to turn those into useful dates for art historical purposes.

64.65.text: One of the key differences between these two portraits

69.63.text: this one is made from oak

72.79.text: derived from the Eastern Baltic and this one is made from oak derived from somewhere in England

77.06.text: the grain on these is very tight and very straight

81.04.text: and the grain on this one you can see is

84.28.text: much more open and much more skewed this is from a much more branched

88.75.text: and twisted tree and because it is a twisted tree

92.21.text: it is more likely to distort over time

95.42.text: This is a single board panel

98.64.text: there are no joints in this, and the last ring on this board is down in this corner

105.56.text: There is no sapwood visible on this edge so we know this has been trimmed of the outer rings

108.88.text: We have to allow for the minimum amount of missing sapwood

112.37.text: in this case we would use an estimate of a minimum of

116.13.text: ten for English material - - so it is later than 1537

119.18.text: which since it’s a portrait of Edward when he’s relatively young

126.32.text: The tree-ring data for this suggests that it’s from London, Surrey

130.08.text: Hampshire kind of area and it’s about 10mm thick

133.35.text: which is very normal. The material is used

136.56.text: in green form; there is no concept of seasoning in the sixteenth century

139.99.text: The toolmarks on them, and indeed the warping on them

144.03.text: would be much less severe if they had been left to dry properly

151.21.text: so there’s plenty of reasons to suppose that there is a production line of this stuff coming in from the woodlands

155.21.text: coming in off the ports and being turned into panels and being turned into paintings in a relatively short order
